title: Stock Futures Wobble as Inflation Remains in Focus; U.S. retail sales for October, due at 8:30 a.m. ET, are expected to show an increase of 1.2% from the prior month
text:
Stocks have rallied in recent days as data indicated pricing pressures moderated last month for both consumers and suppliers. Investors are betting that a slowdown in inflation will allow the Federal Reserve to ease up on interest-rate increases.

"Clearly there are these hopes for a true peak in inflation and hawkishness from central banks," said Thomas McGarrity, head of equities at RBC Wealth Management.

Investors are also watching corporate earnings for clues on how consumers are coping with inflation and high borrowing costs. Walmart on Tuesday reported stronger-than-expected salesduring the fall quarter, an indication that consumers were looking for deals but still spending ahead of the holiday shopping season.

The results "pointed to some resilience for the U.S. consumer," said Louise Dudley, an equities portfolio manager at Federated Hermes. "A lot of investors will be looking towards how that holiday spending comes through, and whether the consumer does go out and spend or not."

U.S. retail sales data out 8:30 a.m. ET. are expected to show a 1.2% rise in October from the prior month.

The yield on the 10-year U.S. Treasury note slipped to 3.790%, from 3.798% Tuesday. The yield on the two-year note, which is more sensitive to near-term interest rate expectations, edged up 4.361%, from 4.359%. Yields rise as prices fall.

Meanwhile, the U.S. dollar continued to come under pressure, with the WSJ Dollar Index down 0.3%. It remains up more than 10% this year.

Cryptocurrency prices were slightly lower as the fallout from the implosion of crypto exchange FTX spreads. Bitcoin slipped 1.2% from its 5 p.m. ET price to $16,670.73. Ether fell 1.3%.

In commodity markets, prices for Brent crude, the global benchmark, rose 0.5% to $94.38.

European stocks were lower. The Stoxx Europe 600 fell 0.5% while the U.K.'s FTSE 100 slipped 0.1%. The domestic-focused FTSE 250 index fell 1.4% after data showed U.K. inflation rose to a fresh 41-year highin October on surging energy prices.

In Asia, indexes were mixed. Japan's Nikkei 225 gained 0.1%, while Hong Kong's Hang Seng lost 0.5% and China's benchmark Shanghai Composite lost 0.4%. Asian stocks have rallied in recent days as Beijing relaxed its strict Covid-19 measures and unveiled plans to help support its property market.

Write to Chelsey Dulaney at chelsey.dulaney@wsj.com

Stock Futures Wobble as Inflation Remains in Focus
